posts.name: Krypton #9487
posts.cooked: We are programming an elevator, with two neo brushless, using the controller’s internal pidf, with revlib, with a 5:1 reduction, but the elevator’s movement is very slow, can anyone help us?

posts.name: Wilson
posts.cooked: Not well versed with rev controls but could you try increasing the p-value in your loop?

posts.name: Krypton #9487
posts.cooked: We’ve tried, we’ve increased it but there wasn’t a significant difference

posts.name: Ric Ferrell Mentor for 5503 Tiger Trons
posts.cooked:
Whilst I am not an expert…do you have a 3:1 available?  Just to try the settings you currently have.

Outside of that… PID may be an issue.

I would also check the actual motor direction…it MAY be fighting itself.
posts.display_username: Ric Ferrell Mentor for 5503 Tiger Trons

posts.name: Jeffrey Davis
posts.cooked: It might be a hardware problem. Check if you can move the elevator by hand. Do the motors spin freely? Is anything binding? We often run into an issue with the maxplanetary gears where they go together but when you tighten the screws it binds up. A variety of mechanical things can get in the way and it’s worth checking those first.

posts.name: usbcd36
posts.cooked:
Always try to isolate the cause; reduce the number of possible culprits.  If closed-loop control isn’t working, make sure it works under raw human control.

There’s an order to do things for a closed-loop system, stopping if something doesn’t work properly.  Here’s what I recommend for an elevator:

mechanics : (as Practicality says above); does it move easily and smoothly?  Is there an absence of bad sounds?  If not, try to isolate the problem; check with the power on and off, to verify that it’s not just brake mode

sensors : hook them up, make sure you can read them; move your mechanism (robot disabled, by hand!) and watch its position reading change

units : convert from raw sensor to something you have a measurement device for (e.g., meters, inches)

plotting : show sensor readings over time, as well as motor voltage and current

soft limits : figure out how far the mechanism can travel safely and set up limits to prevent the motor from trying to push it beyond the limits

open-loop testing : apply voltage to the motors (with your hand on the stop button!) and make sure it moves as expected; watch the motor current when you do this too and make sure you’re not at the current limit while the elevator is holding position.

gravity feedforward : a constant applied voltage to counteract the effects of gravity (this is required if your elevator isn’t horizontal or completely counterbalanced, and if you’re not using any other exotic control scheme)

setpoint generation : make sure your setpoints are plotted too and that they make sense during open-loop operation before you start trying to close the loop; pretend you are the controller and try to achieve the setpoints manually

other feedforward : optional; this varies, but may include a trapezoidal profile generator to allow for velocity and acceleration feedforward

feedback : start with proportional, then add derivative and integral as needed; integral should usually be avoided in favor of more accurate feedforward

link_counts.title: Introduction to DC Motor Feedforward — FIRST Robotics Competition documentation

posts.name: Patrick
posts.cooked: First of all a 5:1 is only part of your transmission. You should really be looking at the conversion from motor speed to elevator speed which is not a unitless ratio, it will have units of in/rev or similar. Once you have that, you can start calculating things like elevator free speed and stall torque to see if you’re in the right ball park for the speed you want and weight you’re trying to lift.

posts.name: paulonis
posts.cooked:
usbcd36:

units : convert from raw sensor to something you have a measurement device for (e.g., meters, inches)

plotting : show sensor readings over time, as well as motor voltage and current

Fantastic list for startup and troubleshooting!  These two highlighted items seem particularly important for the issue at hand.

The code is set up where the measurement is motor shaft rotations.  I don’t know if that is intended.  It’s not typical.  I’d suggest implementing conversion factors to get the measurement (and setpoints) in inches, meters, millimeters, or some unit representing elevator height.

Is the setpoint for each control loop being entered in motor rotations?

If the motors are coupled together to drive the elevator, it is common for one motor to be set up to follow the other and only one controller is configured to do closed loop control.  This is the safest way to ensure that the motors cannot fight each other.

When the elevator is moving slowly, what voltage is going to each motor?  If the voltage is low, either the controller is not tuned correctly or there is some electrical problem in the system.

posts.name: Casey Stahl - 2358 - Robot Repairman (Mentor)
posts.cooked:
Lots of good advice above.

Make sure you’re testing it loaded.  There can be cantilevering effects when it has a load versus unloaded.  And it’ll use different bearings going up versus going down as the load shifts. The mass of an algae ball at a full extension for example could possibly create a load on a bad bearing (not spinning) that is not present without the algae or during a hand test.

Assuming everything mechanically seems smooth when testing by hand, it may be a small design issue.  (I’m skipping software as I’m not qualified to give advice on it.)

If it’s not smooth you’ve got some assembly issues.  Things need to be square.  Bearings need to spin freely.  And if using a rope, it needs to travel over the pulleys freely as well.  You should be able to pull on the rope/belt and make it move easily by hand.

I didn’t notice a comment on the drum/spool/timing belt pulley diameter yet.  There have been posted designs for both styles of elevator on the forum this year.  111 for example posted both on their build thread if you need a reference.  Or there are many elevator kits like Thrifty Bot, which we’ve used in the past.  Those suppliers also have good support videos.

If using a drum, it may be too small a diameter.  The drum diameter greatly impacts the speed by how much rope/chord is being taken up per revolution.  If your winding around a hex shaft, that’s quite small and going to take many more revolutions compared to a 4" drum/spool.  The same can be said for the pulley (instead of drum) diameter if using timing belts.

Our elevator will be powered by two Krakens, with a gear mesh to keep them sync’d.  If each side is pulling slightly differently it could cause the elevator to rack and add friction.
Run a calculation using amb to see if the gear ratio is appropriate to rule out an incorrect gear ratio. 3:1 will be slower than 5:1 if the gear ratio is already too low.
